Expectation1: Review and analyze legal documents and contracts
Situation1: A purchase agreement needs analysis before an upcoming filing deadline that is drawing nearer.
Expectation2: Attend weekly church services to worship and participate in community activities
Situation2: They think about joining Sunday worship when time allows
Story: Sunday morning, sunlight filtered through my office window as I stared at the thick stack of purchase agreements on my desk. The filing deadline was tomorrow, and my client was counting on me to catch any loopholes or hidden risks. As a lawyer, I knew the gravity of missing something—my reputation and someone’s livelihood were on the line. Yet, my phone buzzed with a reminder: Sunday worship at church. I hadn’t attended in weeks, always telling myself I’d go when time allowed. My faith taught me to honor the Sabbath, to gather with others, to rest and reconnect with God. But the contracts wouldn’t review themselves, and the clock was ticking. My heart ached with guilt—toward my client if I left the work unfinished, toward my faith if I neglected worship again. I sat at my desk, torn, the weight of both roles pressing down, unsure which expectation I would let down this time.
